header.title: Why Women Prefer Male Bosses
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Studies show that when women have a preference, they would choose to have a male boss instead of a female boss. Participants in one study described their female bosses as 'emotional,' 'catty,' or 'bitchy.' Where does this aversion to female bosses come from? And why do some women seem to undercut each other at work?. . Read Olga Khazan's article on The Atlantic for more on the psychology of queen bees: https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/.... . Subscribe to The Atlantic on YouTube: http://bit.ly/subAtlanticYT

I think that it is a mistake to make it easier for women to rise to the top, lest we provoke the idea that they rose because of inappropriate bias. What we want to do is make it harder for women to be overlooked or otherwise discriminated against due to their being women. Making it easier for women to progress in business focuses primarily on the woman's being a woman, and secondarily upon her skills and talents. That will actually hurt th e woman herself, as soon as she detects her womanness as a major factor in her progress. What we want to do is focus, perhaps even more intensely for women than for men, in making sure women have as much freedom and resources as possible to acquire skill and talent. To give them that freedom likely will require us to call it out, to focus more on calling women forth than we would tend to call men forth. This is not a hard and fast rule, but a principle to be applied to all humans, regardless of the ir sex. A male who, for whatever reason tends to lack assertiveness but who has inherent qualities that can be nurtured, should get the same treatment, being called forth so that his skill and talents can be developed. When I se e a woman who has that special indescribable something that signals inherent quality, then, as a leader, I consider it an obligation to decency to go out of my way to make sure nothing gets in the way of helping her qualities develop and flourish. In fact, I have an obligation to go out of my way to call forth those qualities, to let everyone else begin to see them, and even to help me call them forth. It won't do to create the mythical "level playing field" in her case because the field has been built agains t her sex for the past 50,000 years. I understand that many guys will reject this. But those same guys, when faced with a woman, especially a pretty woman, will generally begin responding to her firstly, based on th eir base sexual impulses and not bas ed on the woman's talents and skill. I have seen this a thousand times, even in myself. It is important to me that I vigorously crucify my tende ncy toward sexual response, to instead favor my tendency to appreciate the potential benefits of skill and talent that any particular woman might present. I have an obligation to do this not only for the development of those in my charge, but also for shareholders and for the health of the enterprise in general. There is a domain for sexual dynamics and expression. That domain does not include the progress of employees and development of enterprises - perhaps unless we are dealing with brothels.
